channel.title: physical on Neil Chen
channel.description: Recent content in physical on Neil Chen

item.title: High-quality grappling content
item.description: This is a collection of grappling (jiu-jitsu/wrestling/judo) content that seems consistently high signal-to-noise to me. I’m looking for a high ratio of (footage/analysis of people grappling) : (footage of people talking): The Grapple Club Ayrshire Grappler William Abreu Obviously practicing more grappling is the best way to absorb this information, but during quarantine I’m enjoying these channels.

item.title: Pressure and failure
item.description: This is a running list of some of my favorite accounts of personal rejection or failure (narrowly: in school and in tech). Ian Goodfellow Ian Goodfellow’s name is now roughly synonymous with deep learning, but he describes plenty of personal risks, subsequent failures, and post-facto views on them: I once applied for a summer internship with a Stanford professor. My transcript was included in my application. He replied â€œWhy do you have an A in my class?

item.title: Genki Sudo
item.description: Genki Sudo is a member of the upper house of Japan’s bicameral legislature. Western folks like myself might have unwittingly encountered him via these 2000s music videos of his music group World Order. Before all this, Sudo was a professional mixed martial artist. He fought in several promotions, but in every arena he introduced himself idiosyncratically. Sudo choreographed WWE-like entrances that included: himself doing the robot with a KFC bucket hat, himself as a baseball player, himself in Samurai garb, and ended every fight carrying the flag of his motto, “We Are All One”:
